fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A monoidal category is cartesian if its monoidal product is the cartesian product (and so its monoidal unit is terminal); any category with finite products is monoidal in this way. Dually, it is cocartesian if it has finite coproducts, and bicartesian if it has both.

Categories for the Working Mathematician provides an array of general ideas useful in a wide variety of fields. Starting from the foundations, this book illuminates the concepts of category, functor, natural transformation, and duality. The book then turns to adjoint functors, which provide a description of universal constructions, an analysis of the representations of functors by sets of morphisms, and a means of manipulating direct and inverse limits. These categorical concepts are extensively illustrated in the remaining chapters, which include many applications of the basic existence theorem for adjoint functors. The categories of algebraic systems are constructed from certain adjoint-like data and characterized by Beck's theorem. After considering a variety of applications, the book continues with the construction and exploitation of Kan extensions. This second edition includes a number of revisions and additions, including two new chapters on topics of active interest. One is onsymmetric monoidal categories and braided monoidal categories and the coherence theorems for them. The second describes 2-categories and the higher dimensional categories which have recently come into prominence. The bibliography has also been expanded to cover some of the many other recent advances concerning categories.
A cartesian closed category is bicartesian closed if it additionally has finite coproducts; equivalently, it is a bicartesian category whose cartesian monoidal structure is closed.
A bicartesian category C is distributive if the canonical comparison morphism (A\times B) + (A\times C)\to A\times (B+C) is an isomorphism.
A lattice is a poset with all finite meets and joins; in particular, it is both a meet- and join-semilattice.
Equivalently, it is a posetal bicartesian category.
A meet-pseudosemilattice is a poset with all binary meets. Dually, a join-pseudosemilattice is a poset with all binary joins.
Some authors use semilattice to refer to this notion, using (e.g.) bounded semilattice or semilattice with \top for what we call merely semilattice.
As a category, a meet-pseudosemilattice is a cartesian poset.
A cartesian closed category is a cartesian monoidal category whose monoidal structure is closed. In this case, we call the internal hom [x, y] an exponential object, and write it y^x.
A cartesian category C satisfies the following equations up to natural isomorphism:
By the representability of limits, each of these follows from the corresponding result in Set.
A coproduct is a colimit of a discrete diagram. Its colegs are called coprojections.
A product is a limit of a discrete diagram. Its legs are called projections.
An terminal object is a limit of an empty diagram.
By the universal property of limits, an object t is terminal in the category C if and only if for every object c, there is a unique morphism c\to t.
